title: Multiple System Atrophy (MSA)
icd10: ** G90.3 (Multi-system degeneration of the autonomic nervous system)
scope: ** Diagnosis and comprehensive management of multiple system atrophy (MSA-P and MSA-C) in adults. Covers 2022 MDS diagnostic criteria, autonomic function testing, neuroimaging, symptomatic management of autonomic failure (orthostatic hypotension, urogenital dysfunction), motor symptoms (parkinsonism, cerebellar ataxia), sleep disorders (REM sleep behavior disorder, stridor), and multidisciplinary care. Excludes Parkinson's disease, progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), corticobasal degeneration (CBD), dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), pure autonomic failure (PAF), and hereditary cerebellar ataxias.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline health assessment; rule out anemia contributing to orthostatic symptoms
Electrolytes, renal/hepatic function for medication dosing; hyponatremia screening
Hypothyroidism can cause cerebellar ataxia and autonomic dysfunction
B12 deficiency causes ataxia and autonomic neuropathy
More sensitive for B12 deficiency if level borderline (200-400 pg/mL)
Screen for diabetes/prediabetes causing autonomic neuropathy
UTI screening given urinary retention; recurrent UTIs common in MSA
Neurogenic bladder assessment; PVR ≥100 mL supports MSA diagnosis

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Failure to rise with standing suggests preganglionic lesion (MSA); rise >2x suggests postganglionic (PAF/PD)
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Low-normal supine NE with failure to increase on standing

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Rule out pheochromocytoma if paroxysmal hypertension
Neurosyphilis can cause tabes dorsalis with autonomic failure

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Paraneoplastic antibody panel (anti-Yo, anti-Hu, anti-VGCC, anti-Tr, anti-GAD65)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration if subacute onset

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Genetic testing for hereditary ataxias (SCA1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 17; FXTAS)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: If family history of ataxia or young onset (<50 years)
Emerging biomarker for synucleinopathies; positive in MSA (lower sensitivity than PD)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Higher sensitivity than serum SAA for MSA; helps distinguish from non-synucleinopathies
Elevated in MSA (higher than PD); prognostic biomarker
Emerging biomarker; different distribution pattern than PD (more proximal in MSA)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Serum/urine heavy metals (arsenic, lead, mercury, thallium)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Toxic exposure causing cerebellar or autonomic dysfunction
Adrenomyeloneuropathy (young males with ataxia and autonomic dysfunction)

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain without and with contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.target: MSA-C: "hot cross bun sign" in pons, cerebellar atrophy, MCP atrophy; MSA-P: "putaminal slit sign" (hyperintense lateral putaminal rim on T2), putaminal atrophy, putaminal hypointensity on T2*/SWI
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pacemaker, metallic implants, severe renal disease (gadolinium)

Essential/First-line.target: Putaminal hypointensity (iron deposition) in MSA-P; "putaminal slit sign" more visible
Chronic denervation in external anal sphincter (Onuf's nucleus involvement); general neuropathy screening

Essential/First-line.item: Tilt-table test with continuous BP and HR monitoring (CPT 95924)
Essential/First-line.target: Neurogenic OH: SBP drop ≥20 or DBP drop ≥10 within 3 min without compensatory heart rate increase (HR rise <0.5 bpm per mmHg SBP drop)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Severe aortic stenosis, recent MI, unstable angina

Extended.target: Reduced striatal dopamine transporter uptake (abnormal in MSA-P and PD; does NOT distinguish MSA from PD)
PRESERVED cardiac uptake in MSA (vs. reduced in PD and DLB) — key distinguishing test
Extended.contraindications: Drugs affecting uptake (tricyclics, labetalol); recent MI

Extended.target: MSA-C: cerebellar and brainstem hypometabolism; MSA-P: putaminal hypometabolism; helps distinguish from PD
REM sleep without atonia (RBD); nocturnal stridor; obstructive/central sleep apnea
Reduced/absent sweat response indicating postganglionic sudomotor failure
Widespread anhidrosis pattern (preganglionic pattern in MSA vs. distal in PD)
Neurogenic detrusor overactivity, detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia, incomplete emptying
Vocal cord abductor paralysis (bilateral) — risk for sudden death

Rare/Specialized.item: Cardiac autonomic testing (HR variability, Valsalva maneuver, deep breathing) (CPT 95921, 95922)
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced heart rate variability, abnormal Valsalva ratio, blunted HR response to deep breathing
Chronic neurogenic changes in external anal sphincter (Onuf's nucleus) — early finding in MSA
Quantitative measurement of putaminal, pontine, cerebellar volume loss
Diffusion changes in middle cerebellar peduncles; cross-shaped hyperintensity in pons on DWI

Referrals & Consults.item: Movement disorder specialist for diagnostic confirmation, levodopa trial interpretation, and longitudinal management of parkinsonism/ataxia
Autonomic disorders specialist for comprehensive autonomic function testing and OH management optimization
Urology for neurogenic bladder evaluation, urodynamic studies, and intermittent catheterization training
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation (VFSS or FEES) given progressive bulbar dysfunction and aspiration risk
Physical therapy for gait and balance training, fall prevention, and assistive device fitting (walker, wheelchair)
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, home safety evaluation, and adaptive equipment
Sleep medicine for polysomnography to evaluate RBD, stridor, and sleep apnea
Otolaryngology (ENT) for laryngoscopy if stridor present to evaluate vocal cord function
Pulmonology for respiratory function monitoring if stridor or respiratory compromise
Palliative care for symptom management, goals of care discussions, and advance directive planning given progressive disease course
Social work for caregiver support, community resources, disability applications, and support group referral
Psychiatry for depression, anxiety, or emotional lability management refractory to first-line agents
Nutrition/dietitian for swallowing-safe diet modification, adequate caloric intake, and salt supplementation guidance for OH
Cardiology for evaluation if autonomic cardiac involvement (recurrent syncope, arrhythmias)

Patient/Family Instructions.item: MSA is a progressive neurodegenerative disease; treatments manage symptoms but do not slow progression — early goals of care discussion recommended
Rise slowly from lying to sitting to standing (staged position changes over 1-2 minutes) to minimize orthostatic hypotension episodes
Increase dietary salt intake to 6-10 g/day and fluid intake to 2-2.5 L/day unless contraindicated by heart failure or renal disease
Elevate head of bed 10-15 degrees (4-6 inch blocks) at night to reduce nocturnal supine hypertension and morning orthostatic symptoms
Avoid large carbohydrate-heavy meals (eat smaller, more frequent meals) to prevent postprandial hypotension
Do NOT stop orthostatic hypotension medications abruptly; these require gradual tapering under physician guidance
Report new or worsening stridor (noisy breathing during sleep) immediately — this may indicate vocal cord paralysis requiring urgent evaluation
Fall prevention measures: remove rugs and tripping hazards, install grab bars in bathroom, use walker or wheelchair as prescribed, avoid standing quickly
Avoid alcohol as it worsens orthostatic hypotension and cerebellar ataxia
Avoid medications that worsen OH: diuretics, alpha-blockers, tricyclic antidepressants, sildenafil (use cautiously), nitrates — discuss all new medications with neurologist
Wear medical alert identification indicating MSA and autonomic dysfunction for emergency situations
Advance directives and healthcare proxy should be established early while patient can participate fully in decisions

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Physical exercise (seated exercises, recumbent bike, aquatic therapy) tailored to functional level for cardiovascular health and mobility preservation
Compression garments (waist-high stockings 30-40 mmHg or abdominal binder) worn during daytime upright activities to reduce venous pooling
Bolus water drinking: drink 500 mL (16 oz) of cold water rapidly to transiently raise BP by 20-30 mmHg for 30-60 minutes (pressor effect)
Avoid hot environments, prolonged hot showers/baths, and saunas as heat worsens vasodilation and OH
High-fiber diet with adequate hydration for neurogenic constipation management
Smoking cessation to optimize cardiovascular and respiratory function
Support group referral: The MSA Coalition (www.multiplesystematrophy.org) and Defeat MSA Alliance for patient and caregiver resources
Caregiver respite care planning and caregiver burnout screening given high caregiving demands

differential.features: Sustained excellent levodopa response (>5 years), asymmetric onset, rest tremor, slower progression, no early autonomic failure, no cerebellar signs
differential.tests: DaTscan (abnormal in both); MIBG (reduced in PD, preserved in MSA); clinical response to levodopa

differential.features: Early falls (backward), vertical supranuclear gaze palsy, axial rigidity > limb, frontal cognitive changes, no autonomic failure
differential.tests: MRI ("hummingbird sign" on sagittal, "morning glory sign" on axial); clinical

differential.features: Markedly asymmetric, limb apraxia, alien limb phenomenon, cortical sensory loss, myoclonus, dystonia
Prominent cognitive decline/dementia within 1 year of parkinsonism, visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, neuroleptic sensitivity
differential.tests: Clinical criteria; MIBG (reduced like PD); DaTscan abnormal

differential.features: Autonomic failure WITHOUT motor features (no parkinsonism, no cerebellar ataxia); may convert to MSA over years
differential.tests: Autonomic testing; serial neurological examination; alpha-synuclein SAA

differential.features: Family history, slower progression, absence of autonomic failure (usually), younger onset
differential.tests: Genetic testing; MRI (isolated cerebellar atrophy); family history

differential.features: Males >50, intention tremor, gait ataxia, cognitive decline, MCP sign on MRI; premutation carrier
differential.tests: FMR1 CGG repeat analysis; MRI (symmetric MCP hyperintensity without pontine hot cross bun)

differential.features: Subacute onset, pandysautonomia, may respond to immunotherapy
differential.tests: Ganglionic AChR antibody; response to IVIG/PLEX

differential.features: Subacute cerebellar ataxia, associated malignancy (ovarian, lung, breast, lymphoma)
differential.tests: Paraneoplastic antibodies (anti-Yo, anti-Hu, anti-Tr, anti-VGCC); CT body; PET

differential.features: Temporal relationship to offending medication (antipsychotics, metoclopramide, valproate), symmetric, may resolve with drug withdrawal
differential.tests: Medication history; DaTscan (normal in drug-induced); resolution with drug removal

differential.features: Magnetic gait apraxia, urinary incontinence, cognitive decline (triad); no cerebellar signs
differential.tests: MRI (ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy); large-volume LP with gait improvement

differential.features: Lower-body predominant, stepwise progression, vascular risk factors, subcortical white matter disease
differential.tests: MRI (extensive white matter disease, lacunar infarcts); vascular risk factor profile

differential.features: Age <50, liver disease, psychiatric features, Kayser-Fleischer rings, wing-beating tremor
differential.tests: Ceruloplasmin, 24-hour urine copper, slit lamp exam; MRI ("face of the giant panda" sign)

disposition.criteria: Most MSA patients managed primarily as outpatients; stable autonomic symptoms on current regimen; ambulatory with or without assistive device; adequate home support; able to maintain oral intake

Recurrent syncope despite outpatient OH management; severe symptomatic orthostatic hypotension requiring IV fluids and medication titration; new dysphagia with aspiration risk; fall with injury; urinary retention requiring catheterization; need for autonomic function testing not available outpatient

Acute stridor with respiratory compromise (vocal cord paralysis); severe autonomic instability (labile BP with end-organ compromise); aspiration pneumonia with respiratory failure; cardiovascular collapse from refractory OH
OH symptoms controlled on oral medications; safe swallowing confirmed; urinary management plan established; falls risk assessed and mitigated; follow-up scheduled within 1-2 weeks

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Refractory autonomic crises; need for tracheostomy evaluation; respiratory failure; cardiovascular instability not responding to floor-level interventions
Advanced disease with recurrent aspiration, inability to maintain nutrition, respiratory failure, recurrent life-threatening autonomic crises; patient/family goals aligned with comfort-focused care
